If you miss a dose, double up the next day.
questions.rationale: Levothyroxine should be taken in the morning on an empty stomach, with water, at least 30-60 minutes before breakfast for best absorption[77][78]. Other medications (especially calcium, iron, antacids) or food can interfere with its absorption. Bedtime is not typical (and certainly not with a snack). Patients should not double up doses if one is missed; they should take the missed dose as soon as possible or skip if it’s close to the next dose per provider instructions.

questions.stem: Which statement by a patient on levothyroxine (Synthroi
options: I know I will likely need to take this medication for the rest of my life.
I will report chest pain or a rapid heartbeat to my doctor right away.
I can stop taking this if my thyroid levels return to normal.”d. “I should not switch brands of this medication without checking with my doctor.
indicates a need for further teaching?
questions.rationale: Hypothyroidism is typically a chronic condition; levothyroxine replacement is usually lifelong[7][47]. Even if thyroid levels normalize, it’s because of the medication. Stopping it would cause levels to drop again. The patient should indeed report signs of overtreatment like chest pain or tachycardia (possible hyperthyroid symptoms from excessive dose). Also, consistency in brand is important because different brands or generics may vary slightly in potency; any switch should be monitored with lab tests. So option c indicates misunderstanding.

questions.stem: A patient with hyperthyroidism is started on propylthiouracil (PTU). What is the most serious side effect the nurse will educate the patient about?
options: Sore throat or fever (agranulocytosis)
Hair loss
Weight gain
Tinnitus
questions.rationale: Propylthiouracil (and similar thionamides like methimazole) can cause agranulocytosis – a dangerous drop in WBCs. Early signs include sore throat, fever, or other infection signs[79]. Patients must report those immediately. Hair loss can occur initially but is not the most dangerous. Weight gain may occur as thyroid levels normalize (from hyper- to euthyroid), but it’s expected and not dangerous. Tinnitus is not associated with PTU.

questions.stem: What important instruction should the nurse give a female patient of childbearing age who is starting propylthiouracil (PTU) for hyperthyroidism?
options: Notify your provider immediately if you suspect you are pregnant, as PTU is generally preferred in the first trimester.
This medication will make your birth control pills more effective.
Do not take this drug if you plan to become pregnant; it’s completely contraindicated.
Increase your iodine intake while on PTU to help it work.
questions.rationale: PTU is actually the preferred antithyroid medication during the first trimester of pregnancy (because methimazole has teratogenic effects in the first trimester)[79]. After the first trimester, patients are usually switched to methimazole due to PTU’s liver toxicity risk. So if the patient becomes pregnant, the provider needs to know to manage therapy appropriately. PTU doesn’t increase birth control effectiveness (no such interaction). It’s not absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy (methimazole is more so in first trimester). Increasing iodine intake (unless directed for specific therapy) is not advised; excess iodine can actually affect thyroid function unpredictably.

questions.stem: A patient with diabetes insipidus is receiving desmopressin (DDAVP) nasal spray. Which outcome indicates the medication is having the desired effect?
options: Decreased urine output and increased urine specific gravity
Increased thirst and fluid intake
Lower blood glucose levels
Reduced blood pressure
questions.rationale: Diabetes insipidus causes large volumes of dilute urine due to ADH deficiency. Desmopressin is an ADH analog[80]. Its effectiveness is shown by the urine output decreasing to normal and urine becoming more concentrated (higher specific gravity)[81]. Thirst should decrease as fluid balance is restored, not increase. It does not directly affect blood glucose. It may raise blood pressure if it was low (from dehydration), but the primary measure is urine output normalization.

questions.stem: A patient on desmopressin (DDAVP) should be monitored for which electrolyte imbalance?
options: Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia
Hypercalcemia
Hypomagnesemia
questions.rationale: Desmopressin causes water retention by concentrating urine. If water intake is excessive or dose too high, it can lead to dilutional hyponatremia (low sodium)[81][82], which can cause confusion, headache, or even seizures. It doesn’t typically affect potassium, calcium, or magnesium directly, but hyponatremia is a well-known risk from water intoxication.

questions.stem: The nurse is monitoring a patient with preeclampsia receiving magnesium sulfate IV. Which assessment finding indicates magnesium toxicity?
options: Absent patellar reflexes and respiratory rate of 10/min
Blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg and 3+ deep tendon reflexes
Complaint of flushing and feeling warm
Fetal heart rate of 150 bpm
questions.rationale: Magnesium sulfate toxicity signs include loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) and respiratory depression (resp <12). Absent patellar reflexes and a RR of 10 are clear toxicity signs requiring intervention (stop mag, give calcium gluconate antidote). BP 150/95 with brisk reflexes indicates preeclampsia still active, but not mag toxicity (toxic would cause low BP and no reflexes). Flushing and warmth are common side effects at therapeutic levels, not necessarily toxicity. Fetal heart of 150 is within normal range for fetus, not a direct indicator of mag toxicity.

questions.stem: Which action is a priority for a patient receiving IV magnesium sulfate?
options: Keep calcium gluconate readily available in case of overdose.
Monitor blood glucose every 15 minutes.
Encourage ambulation to reduce edema.
Administer the infusion rapidly to ensure therapeutic levels.
questions.rationale: Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity and must be on hand whenever magnesium is given IV (as in eclampsia/preeclampsia management). Frequent blood glucose checks are not relevant to magnesium therapy. The patient on mag sulfate (often a preeclamptic woman) will usually be on bed rest (mag causes sedation and fall risk). Magnesium must be given via controlled infusion pump, not rapidly (rapid infusion can cause cardiac or respiratory arrest). Priority is safety: have the antidote available.

questions.stem: A woman in preterm labor is receiving terbutaline (Brethine). Which maternal assessment finding would cause the nurse to be concerned?
options: Maternal heart rate of 132 beats/min
Blood glucose of 120 mg/dL
Report of tremors and restlessness
Blood pressure of 138/86 mmHg
questions.rationale: Terbutaline, a beta-2 agonist tocolytic, often causes maternal tachycardia. A maternal HR of 132 is high (tachycardia) and might warrant holding or adjusting the dose, especially if accompanied by other symptoms. Tremors and restlessness are common side effects (beta-agonist stimulation). A BP of 138/86 is not alarming (terbutaline can cause transient hypotension, but that BP is fine). Blood glucose can rise with terbutaline, but 120 mg/dL is not particularly concerning. The significantly elevated heart rate is the bigger concern.

questions.stem: Which of the following is an expected side effect of terbutaline (Brethine) when given to a pregnant woman to stop contractions?
options: Maternal tachycardia and palpitations
Uterine cramping and increased contractions
Severe hypotension
Fetal bradycardia
questions.rationale: Terbutaline often causes maternal tachycardia, palpitations, tremor, and nervousness due to beta-adrenergic stimulation. It relaxes the uterus, so it should decrease contractions (not increase them). It can cause a modest drop in blood pressure, but severe hypotension is not common at tocolytic doses. The fetus might experience some tachycardia as well (due to maternal drug crossing), not usually bradycardia.

questions.stem: Rho(
options: An Rh-negative mother who delivered an Rh-positive baby, with a negative direct Coombs test on the infant
An Rh-positive mother with an Rh-negative baby
An Rh-negative mother with an Rh-negative babyd. An Rh-positive mother with an Rh-positive baby
immune globulin (RhoGAM) is ordered for a postpartum patient. In which situation is RhoGAM indicated?
questions.rationale: RhoGAM is given to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive, to prevent the mother from developing antibodies against Rh-positive blood. A negative Coombs test indicates the mother has not yet formed antibodies, so RhoGAM is effective prophylaxis. It is typically given within 72 hours postpartum[58]. It’s not needed if the baby is Rh-negative (no Rh antigen to sensitize the mom). If the mother is Rh-positive, she doesn’t need RhoGAM regardless of baby’s status.

questions.stem: A pregnant patient at 28 weeks’ gestation is Rh-negative. Her antibody screen is negative. What order does the nurse anticipate?
options: Administer Rho(
No RhoGAM is needed until after delivery.
Start the patient on weekly RhoGAM injections until delivery.d. RhoGAM is only given if the antibody screen is positive.
immune globulin (RhoGAM) now and again after delivery if the infant is Rh-positive.
questions.rationale: Standard prophylaxis is to give Rh-negative mothers RhoGAM at around 28 weeks gestation (if antibody screen is negative) and again within 72 hours postpartum if the newborn is Rh-positive[58]. So option a is correct. If the antibody screen were positive, it’s too late for prophylaxis (it means she’s already sensitized). Weekly injections are not protocol (it’s typically a single dose at 28 weeks). It is not withheld until after delivery; the 28-week dose is important.

questions.stem: A patient with breast cancer is taking tamoxifen (Nolvadex). The nurse instructs the patient to report which possible serious adverse effect of tamoxifen?
options: Abnormal vaginal bleeding
Hot flashes
Dry skin
Weight loss
questions.rationale: Tamoxifen, a SERM, can cause endometrial hyperplasia and even endometrial cancer. Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding can be a sign of endometrial cancer and should be reported[83][84]. Tamoxifen also increases risk of thromboembolism, so leg swelling/pain or sudden shortness of breath (clot signs) should be reported. Hot flashes are a common side effect but not life-threatening. Dry skin and weight loss are not notable issues with tamoxifen (it more often causes slight weight gain if anything).

questions.stem: When teaching a patient about tamoxifen (Nolvadex), which statement is correct?
options: Tamoxifen may increase your risk of blood clots, so report calf pain or swelling immediately.
This medication will prevent any menopause-like symptoms.
Tamoxifen can be taken short-term for a few weeks to treat your cancer.
You should avoid all calcium-rich foods while on tamoxifen.
questions.rationale: Tamoxifen has estrogen-agonist effects in some tissues, leading to increased risk of thromboembolic events (DVT, PE, stroke)[83]. Patients should promptly report symptoms of clots. It actually causes menopause-like symptoms such as hot flashes. It’s usually taken for years (5-10 years) as part of breast cancer treatment/prevention, not just a few weeks. There’s no dietary restriction for calcium; in fact maintaining bone health is important because tamoxifen can help bones, but diet isn’t restricted.

questions.stem: Which patient should not be prescribed combined oral contraceptive pills containing ethinyl estradiol/norgestimate (Ortho Tri-Cyclen)?
options: A 38-year-old smoker with hypertension
A 22-year-old who has never smoked
A 30-year-old with polycystic ovary syndrome
A 25-year-old who takes acetaminophen occasionally
questions.rationale: Combined oral contraceptives (containing estrogen) are contraindicated in women over 35 who smoke, because of a significantly increased risk of thromboembolism (blood clots), stroke, and myocardial infarction. A 38-year-old smoker with hypertension has multiple risk factors, so she should avoid combined OCPs[83]. The others have no strong contraindications: a young non-smoker, PCOS often is treated with OCPs, and acetaminophen has no interaction.

questions.stem: A patient on Ortho Tri-Cyclen birth control pills missed two consecutive doses. What should the nurse instruct her to do?
options: Follow the package instructions: you may need to take two pills for the next two days and use backup contraception.
Stop the pack and discard it, then start a new pack immediately.
It’s fine, just continue one pill daily; the effectiveness isn’t affected until three or more pills are missed.
Double the dose today and no backup method is necessary.
questions.rationale: If two active pills are missed, most oral contraceptive guidelines suggest taking two pills as soon as remembered (or two pills per day for two days) and using backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for at least 7 days because effectiveness is reduced. The exact instructions can vary slightly by brand, but generally doubling up and backup is needed[85]. Stopping the pack is usually advised if more than two are missed or if certain weeks are missed, but not for just two. Effectiveness is affected by missing two pills, so backup is needed. Simply doubling once is not enough without backup. Always check the specific pill’s instructions, but option a captures the typical approach.

questions.stem: A 40-year-old patient with chronic pain is taking morphine sulfate (MS Contin) extended-release tablets twice daily. What important teaching point should the nurse emphasize?
options: Do not crush or chew the extended-release tablets.
Avoid taking this medication with food.
Stop the medication if you develop constipation.
You can drive as long as you feel normal on the medication.
questions.rationale: Extended-release opioid tablets (like MS Contin) must be swallowed whole. Crushing or chewing them would release the drug rapidly, risking overdose[86][87]. Taking with food is often fine (and can help prevent stomach upset); no need to avoid food unless directed. Constipation is expected with opioids; the patient should manage it (fluids, fiber, laxatives/stool softeners), not abruptly stop medication without guidance. Patients should be cautioned about driving or operating machinery until they know how the med affects them (opioids can cause drowsiness). The priority here is the safety issue of not altering the form of the ER tablet.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a post-operative patient on morphine PCA (Patient-Controlled Analgesia). Which assessment finding is most concerning?
options: Respiratory rate of 8 breaths/minute
Pinpoint pupils
The patient falls asleep easily but arouses to name
Constipation on the second post-op day
questions.rationale: A respiratory rate of 8/min is too low and indicates significant opioid-induced respiratory depression, which is an urgent concern. Pinpoint pupils are an expected effect of opioids (miosis) but not life-threatening by itself. Sedation (falls asleep easily) is an expected side effect as long as the patient can be aroused and respirations are adequate. Constipation is common with opioids and can be managed; it’s not acute. The low respiratory rate is most concerning, possibly requiring intervention like reducing dose or giving naloxone if severe.

questions.stem: Before administering an IV dose of morphine for pain, the nurse notes the patient’s blood pressure is 88/50 mmHg and respiratory rate is 10/min. What is the nurse’s best action?
options: Hold the morphine and notify the provider of the vital signs.
Administer the morphine and recheck vital signs in 15 minutes.
Give half the ordered dose now and half in 30 minutes.
Position the patient flat and give the morphine to prevent hypotension.
questions.rationale: Morphine can cause vasodilation and respiratory depression. The patient already has hypotension and bradypnea (10/min is lowish). It’s safest to hold the dose and clarify with the provider given these values. Administering it could worsen both BP and RR. The nurse should not unilaterally halve the dose or attempt to “prevent” hypotension by positioning; the issue is the patient may not tolerate more opioid at this time. Notifying the provider allows for dose adjustment or alternative pain management in light of vital signs.

questions.stem: A patient received hydromorphone (Dilaudi
options: Gently stimulate the patient and coach deep breaths.
Administer naloxone per protocol.
Increase the IV fluid rate.d. Place the patient in Trendelenburg position.
2 mg IV for severe pain. Fifteen minutes later, the patient is very drowsy, with a respiratory rate of 8/min and oxygen saturation of 89%. What should the nurse do first?
questions.rationale: For a patient with opioid-induced respiratory depression, the initial step is to attempt to arouse them and prompt breathing while preparing for further intervention. If the patient does not improve quickly with stimulation or is difficult to arouse, then naloxone (opioid antagonist) should be given to reverse the opioid effect[88][89]. However, since the question says “very drowsy” (not unresponsive) and RR 8 with sat 89, the nurse can try stimulation first. Naloxone is appropriate if the patient cannot be roused to adequately improve respirations. IV fluids and Trendelenburg won’t help respiratory depression; Trendelenburg is for hypotension.

questions.stem: A patient is receiving IV hydromorphone (Dilaudi
options: Hydromorphone is more potent than morphine, so a smaller dose provides equivalent pain relief.
They are exactly the same; only the name is different.
Hydromorphone lasts much longer, that’s why we use it.”d. “Hydromorphone has no side effects, unlike morphine.
for post-op pain. The new nurse asks how hydromorphone compares to morphine. The best response is:
questions.rationale: Hydromorphone is approximately 5-7 times more potent than morphine; thus, lower milligram doses are used to achieve similar analgesia[31][90]. It is not exactly the same (different drug, different potency). Its duration is similar to morphine (maybe slightly shorter for immediate release forms), not much longer. It has similar opioid side effects (respiratory depression, constipation, etc.) as morphine. So highlighting potency (and thus careful dosing) is key.

questions.stem: A patient on patient-controlled analgesia (PC
options: with hydromorphone (Dilaudi
Thank the son for helping and continue to monitor the patient’s pain.
Disable the PCA pump and switch to PRN nurse-administered boluses.d. Increase the PCA dose to overcome the missed doses when the patient was sleeping.

is not getting adequate pain relief. The nurse discovers the patient’s teenage son has been pressing the PCA button to help her “stay comfortable.” What is the appropriate nursing action?a. Instruct the son that only the patient should press the button, and explain the risks of oversedation.
questions.rationale: Only the patient should press the PCA button (called “patient-controlled” for that reason). Family members should not activate PCA dosing because it can lead to oversedation if the patient doesn’t need the dose (especially if the patient is sleeping)[88]. The nurse should explain this safety principle to the son. It is not appropriate to thank him for doing something unsafe. Disabling PCA or switching therapy isn’t necessary if the issue is misuse; rather, re-educate and ensure proper usage. Increasing the dose is dangerous if the problem is that the son was dosing while mom slept, potentially causing sedation.

questions.stem: A cancer patient is taking oxycodone extended-release (OxyContin) 40 mg every 12 hours for chronic pain. What instruction is critical for the safe use of this medication?
options: Swallow the tablet whole; do not crush, chew, or break it.
Take this medication whenever pain is above a 5 out of 10.
Avoid taking any immediate-release pain medication with this drug.
Stop this medication if you experience any drowsiness.
questions.rationale: Extended-release oxycodone (OxyContin) must be swallowed whole; crushing or chewing can release a potentially fatal dose at once[86]. It’s taken on a scheduled basis (every 12 hours), not prn based on pain rating (immediate-release versions are used prn for breakthrough). Patients can still take prescribed breakthrough immediate-release opioids along with ER as directed. Drowsiness is an expected side effect initially; they shouldn’t stop the med but rather consult their provider if side effects are concerning. The critical safety point is not to tamper with the ER tablet.

questions.stem: A patient on oxycodone/acetaminophen (Percocet) 5/325 for post-op pain asks if they can take Tylenol for a headache. What is the nurse’s best response?
options: Be careful not to exceed 3,000 mg of acetaminophen in 24 hours from all sources.
Yes, acetaminophen (Tylenol) is fine; it’s not related to Percocet.
No, you should not take any acetaminophen while on Percocet.
Take ibuprofen instead of Tylenol while you’re on Percocet.
questions.rationale: Percocet contains acetaminophen (325 mg per tablet). It’s safe to take acetaminophen separately as long as the total dose of acetaminophen from all sources does not exceed the recommended maximum (generally 3,000–4,000 mg per day, with 3,000 mg being a safer threshold)[86]. The nurse should help the patient calculate their intake. Saying Tylenol is “fine” without qualification is unsafe because of potential overdose. It’s not absolutely forbidden to take any Tylenol, but the total must be limited. Suggesting ibuprofen is an alternative for a headache, but the key is to educate about total acetaminophen dosing rather than outright banning it.

questions.stem: A terminal cancer patient has a fentanyl (Duragesi
options: I will avoid using a heating pad over the patch.
I change the patch every three days as directed.”c. “I disposed of the old patch by flushing it down the toilet.
transdermal patch for pain. Which comment by the patient indicates a need for more education?
I sometimes cut the patch in half if I feel I need a lower dose.
questions.rationale: Fentanyl patches should never be cut, as this can cause rapid release of the drug and risk overdose. Using heat over the patch can increase absorption dangerously – patient knows to avoid that, which is correct. Patches are generally changed every 72 hours (3 days), which is correct. Flushing used patches is recommended (or put in a patch disposal unit) to safely dispose of potent residual fentanyl and avoid accidental exposure. Cutting the patch is incorrect and dangerous.

questions.stem: Which patient scenario is most appropriate for a fentanyl (Duragesi
options: A 50-year-old with chronic cancer pain who has difficulty swallowing pills
A 34-year-old with acute postoperative pain 6 hours after surgeryc. A 19-year-old with intermittent migraine headaches
transdermal patch for analgesia?
A 70-year-old opioid-naïve patient with sudden severe ankle fracture pain
questions.rationale: Fentanyl patches are indicated for chronic, stable opioid requirements (like chronic cancer pain) and in patients who are opioid-tolerant[85]. It provides long-acting pain control but is not suitable for acute or intermittent pain due to its slow onset (it takes ~12-24 hours to reach full effect). For acute post-op or fracture pain in opioid-naïve patients, short-acting opioids are appropriate. A migraine is intermittent acute pain – a patch is not appropriate (they need acute treatment). The 50-year-old with chronic cancer pain is the best fit.

questions.stem: A patient with a heroin overdose is given IV naloxone (Narcan). What should the nurse monitor for after naloxone administration?
options: Return of pain and opioid withdrawal symptoms
Severe hypotension
Sedation
Pupillary constriction
questions.rationale: Naloxone rapidly reverses opioids, which in an addict can precipitate acute withdrawal (symptoms: agitation, nausea/vomiting, sweating, tachycardia, etc.)[88][89]. Also, for someone using opioids for pain, reversal brings the pain back suddenly. Naloxone can also cause a surge in sympathetic activity leading to hypertension and tachycardia (not usually hypotension). It actually reverses sedation, causing alertness or agitation (not sedation). Pupils would dilate as opioid effect is removed (reversing pinpoint pupils).

questions.stem: After administering naloxone (Narcan) to a patient for opioid overdose, the patient wakes up and is now in severe pain and very agitate
options: Stay with the patient, provide reassurance, and manage pain as ordered (e.g., non-opioid analgesics or carefully titrated opioids).
Give another dose of naloxone to ensure all opioid is reversed.
Apply restraints to prevent harm due to agitation.d. Leave the patient briefly to notify the provider of the reaction.
The nurse’s best action is:
questions.rationale: Naloxone has reversed the opioid, which is expected to bring back pain and possibly cause withdrawal symptoms (agitation). The nurse should stay with the patient (safety, reassurance), and treat pain or withdrawal per orders (maybe use non-opioid methods or carefully re-titrate opioids if appropriate once airway is secure). Another dose of naloxone isn’t indicated if the patient is awake and in pain (that would worsen pain/agitation). Restraints are a last resort and only if the patient is a danger; first use de-escalation and symptom management. Notifying the provider is important but should be done without leaving the patient alone – perhaps use a call for assistance, etc. The immediate actions are to comfort and monitor.

questions.stem: Succinylcholine (Anectine) is used during rapid sequence intubation for anesthesi
options: Shortly after administration, the patient’s jaw and body become rigid, and their temperature rises rapidly. What medication should the nurse prepare to administer?a. Dantrolene (Dantrium) IV
Naloxone (Narcan) IV
Neostigmine IV
Epinephrine IV
questions.rationale: The scenario describes signs of malignant hyperthermia (muscle rigidity, sudden fever) triggered by succinylcholine (and possibly inhaled anesthetics). The treatment is IV dantrolene, a muscle relaxant that specifically treats malignant hyperthermia by reducing calcium release in muscles[91][34]. Naloxone reverses opioids (not relevant here). Neostigmine reverses non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (not succinylcholine, a depolarizing type). Epinephrine is for anaphylaxis or cardiac arrest, not for malignant hyperthermia.

questions.stem: What is the primary purpose of administering succinylcholine (Anectine) to a patient during emergency intubation?
options: To induce rapid skeletal muscle paralysis for intubation
To provide deep anesthesia and pain relief during surgery
To reverse narcotic overdose symptoms in surgery
To dry up secretions before intubation
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that causes rapid paralysis, facilitating endotracheal intubation by relaxing muscles (including those of ventilation). It does not provide anesthesia or analgesia – patients still feel pain and are conscious if not given sedatives (it’s crucial to give sedation with it because it only paralyzes). It’s not an opioid or overdose treatment. Anticholinergics like atropine are used to dry secretions, not succinylcholine. So its primary role is to cause muscle paralysis for intubation.

questions.stem: Which statement correctly describes a key difference between succinylcholine (Anectine) and non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium?
options: Succinylcholine causes an initial muscle fasciculation (twitch) before paralysis, whereas vecuronium does not.
Succinylcholine’s effects can be reversed by neostigmine, while vecuronium cannot.
Patients on succinylcholine remain fully conscious and pain-sensitive, unlike with vecuronium.
Succinylcholine has no serious side effects, whereas vecuronium can cause malignant hyperthermia.
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine depolarizes the muscle endplate, causing initial transient muscle fasciculations (twitching) before flaccid paralysis. Non-depolarizing agents like vecuronium simply block receptor without fasciculations. Non-depolarizers can be reversed with cholinesterase inhibitors (neostigmine), whereas succinylcholine’s effect isn’t reversed by neostigmine (it’s actually prolonged by it if given too early). Both types require sedation/analgesia since they cause paralysis without affecting consciousness or pain perception – that’s true for both, not different. Malignant hyperthermia is associated with succinylcholine (and volatile anesthetics), not vecuronium[92][34].

questions.stem: A patient in the ICU is on a ventilator and receiving vecuronium, a neuromuscular blocking agent. What is the priority nursing assessment?
options: Ensure the patient is receiving adequate sedation and analgesia.
Monitor the patient’s urine output hourly.
Check for bowel sounds and abdominal distension.
Assess the patient’s pain level by asking yes/no questions.
questions.rationale: Neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium paralyze skeletal muscles including those for movement and breathing, but they do not affect consciousness or pain. Thus, a paralyzed patient could be awake and in pain but unable to communicate. The priority is to ensure the patient is properly sedated and has analgesia to prevent awareness and suffering while paralyzed. Monitoring urine output and GI function are general ICU cares but not specific priorities of the paralytic itself. Assessing pain by asking may not be possible if intubated and paralyzed. The nurse must assume potential pain and anxiety and treat accordingly.

questions.stem: Which of the following is true about dantrolene (Dantrium)?
options: It is used to treat malignant hyperthermia by reducing muscle contraction.
It reverses the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants.
It is a narcotic analgesic used for post-operative pain.
It treats muscle spasms by central nervous system depression only.
questions.rationale: Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the muscle cells to reduce calcium release, thereby reducing muscle contractions. It is the specific life-saving treatment for malignant hyperthermia[91]. It also can be used for spasticity in conditions like MS (works peripherally on muscle). It doesn’t “reverse” neuromuscular blockers (acetylcholinesterase inhibitors do that for non-depolarizers). It’s not an analgesic. It doesn’t act via CNS depression like baclofen; it acts directly on muscle.

questions.stem: A patient with a history of spinal cord injury has severe muscle spasticity. The physician prescribes dantrolene (Dantrium). What should the nurse include in the teaching?
options: We will monitor your liver function periodically, as this medication can affect the liver.
Avoid any movement or exercise while on this drug to prevent injury.
This medication may cause your urine to turn orange; it’s harmless.
Increase your dose if you don’t feel improvement in a week.
questions.rationale: Chronic use of dantrolene carries a risk of hepatotoxicity. Liver enzymes should be monitored, and patients should be informed to watch for signs of liver dysfunction (e.g., jaundice, fatigue)[91]. There’s no need to avoid all movement/exercise; in fact, therapy might include exercise for rehab, just carefully. Dantrolene doesn’t typically discolor urine (orange urine is more rifampin or sulfasalazine side effect). Dose changes should be made by the physician; patient should not self-increase as it can be dangerous (especially with liver risk).
